plist.p: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to Rome. Before starting this presentation and handing over to the top management, Mr. Fulvio Conti, the Chief Executive; and Mr. Luigi Ferraris, the Chief Financial Officer, let me underline that as you may see today, we are not having dedicated slot of presentations for Endesa and Enel Green Power. Those business cases would be discussed in dedicated Investor Days which you see indicated in this chart, as for your agenda. Naturally, the top management of these two companies as well as all the managers and the divisional directors of the group are here to address the Q&A session.
So, thank you again for coming up. And let me hand over to Fulvio Conti for the start of our presentation.
Good morning, again. Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to our traditional presentation, the strategic plan and the annual results plan for 2012-2016, which you'll see interesting.

In 2011, our Group has continued to deliver a set of solid results. Once again in line with targets, notwithstanding the many crisis that we have seen in the recent years and in particular the worsening of the economies during the fourth quarter of 2011. This crisis is expected to continue as for mature markets as Italy and Iberia, especially during the first half of this year, 2012, while I – we do expect emerging markets economies to confirm their solid growth.

That said we're convinced that starting 2013 onward also Italy and Iberia will see a recovery in their economies. And emerging markets, we'll continue to expand. The management undertakings in terms of CapEx optimization, improved efficiencies and balance sheet strengthening will confirm the capability of the Group to deliver fundamental results coupled with financial discipline.

So first let me handle 2011. I will talk through the macro environment and Luigi will follow with – will follow on with the results. In 2011 – if I may have the slides? Is someone moving on the slides or it's me? It's me. In 2011, we faced markets growing at two different speeds. Since the last couple of years, mature markets have been experiencing low growth rates with stagnating and decreasing GDP as well as lower industrial output. This trend accelerated in 2011 fourth quarter and is expected to continue in the first half of 2012.

Most of the economies are indicating that there are ways and means that the economies might bounce back in the second half of this year. In contrast, emerging markets are experiencing higher growth sustained by a very important demographic expansion, resource availability and stable governments and regulations. All of this had an impact on the energy industry.

As you can see from this slide – slide coming, there it goes. As you can see in this slide, growth markets showed a different pace of electricity demand evolution compared with mature ones. In mature markets, we experienced no growth on electricity demand due to the impact of the crisis. And this has been offset by an ongoing demand expansion in emerging markets.

The persisting state of crisis of the last years led the industry to cut capacity for a total amount of about 56 gigawatts. Within this framework, Enel is taking advantage of its geographic diversification and its well-balanced mix of regulated and unregulated activities. As you will see in a moment, this balanced mix has delivered a good set of results despite the ongoing deterioration of the macro environment in the year.
Now, let me hand it over to our CFO, Luigi, who will be explaining to all of us the 2011 financial results in detail.

S, thank you, Fulvio, and good morning, ladies and gentlemen. First, I'm going to give you some financial highlights. Then, I will take you through the 2011 divisional financial results, ending with our Group's net debt evolution. Group EBITDA increased by 1.4% mainly driven by Infrastructure and Networks, Enel Green Power, the International division and the Market division. Net of non-recurring items of about €300 million 2011 EBITDA was in line with 2010.

Group net income has decreased by 5.5%, totaling about €4.1 billion. Bear in mind that these results has been affected by the amendment to the so-called Robin Hood Tax. Furthermore, Group net ordinary income takes into account as a negative adjustment the above mentioned non-recurring items and the deferred tax impact of the Robin Hood Tax. And this has been compensated for by some positive adjustments mainly related to some write-downs, Endesa Ireland, Edesur in Argentina and Enel Green Power in Greece.

The Board of Directors has decided to propose to the Annual General Meeting a total dividend of €0.26 per share of which €0.10 already paid in November and $0.16 to be paid in June 2012. This is based on a 60% dividend payout policy applied to Enel's net ordinary income reported in 2011. Net debt decreased during the period of about €300 million. I will provide more detail on this, of course, later on in the presentation.

Our net financial charges stands at €3 billion registering a decrease of €174 million, mainly as a result of the following: lower interest charges of €74 million as the positive impact of the lower net financial debt position has more than offset higher interest charge paid on the variable short-term debt. The decrease of other items by €100 million was mainly due to a negative one-off item recorded in 2010, relating to Spanish tariff deficit, which we already mentioned on the occasion of the nine months 2011 result presentation.

Also let me remind you that our normalized annual average cost of gross debt stands at 4.9% versus about 4.6% of last year. Finally, the Group's tax rate increased from about 30% in 2010 to about 37% in 2011. These higher taxes are mainly the result of the inclusion of the Robin Hood Tax in our accounts.

Let's now continue with an update on forward sales activity. Well, in Italy, we have hedged 85% of our 2012 production at an average base load price of about €75 per megawatt hour, and 40%, 45% of 2013, including the roll-over at an average base load price of about €78 per megawatt hour. In particular, for the forward sales related to 2012, spark spreads declined by about €5 per megawatt hour versus 2011. And this, of course, will be reflected in 2012 results, as you will see during the course of our presentation.

In Spain, we are fully hedged for 2012 at 5%-10% for 2013 at an average price of about €55 per megawatt hour and €57 per megawatt hour when it comes to 2013. In Latin America, we are 70%-75% hedged for 2012 and 60%-65% when it comes to 2013. In Slovakia, as usual, we are 100% hedged for the entire 2012 and about 40% for 2013. Prices €56 per megawatt hour refers to 2012 and about €52 when it comes to 2013.

Now, let's move to explain our EBITDA evolution in the following chart, which gives you an overview of how the different divisions have contributed to our EBITDA 2011. Starting with analogies of Generation and Energy Management, well, as you can see in the chart, overall divisional EBITDA declined by €210 million. This is mainly the result of a decrease in the generation margin of €480 million caused by lower margins and prices achieved versus 2010, coupled with the ongoing lower hydroelectricity during 2011; a reduction on €84 million in the gas at trading margin mainly due to the gas price drop for final clients; an increase of €300 million in other items mainly thanks to the revaluation of Trento's Hydro Dolomiti Enel assets as we have already stated again during the course of the nine months presentation.

Moving to domestic Infrastructure and Network division, well, we reported a strong set of results here. EBITDA increased to €4,285 million or 12% up versus last year. This is mainly the results of the following: higher connection fees of €220 million related to energy producer. Let me remind you that during the course of 2011, we have connected about the equivalent of 10,000 gigawatts versus 2% (12:28) gigawatts in 2010 and €286 million, mainly thanks to personnel related provision release and quality premiums received for the improvement in the quality of the service rendered to the final customers.

Moving to the International division, EBITDA increased by about €122 million versus last year. In the Centrel region, Slovenské Elektrárne recorded an increase of €99 million, mainly attributed to the net positive effect of CO2 sales and to a discounts on the transmission tariff linked to some onerous contracts.

Southeastern Europe recorded a decrease of €29 million as a consequence of the assets sold in Bulgaria during the course of 2011. Russia increased by about €57 million, with generation activities contributing €14 million as a result of the growth of energy margin, mainly thanks to higher spreads on free power sales, partially offset by the negative year-on-year difference in the release of a water tax provision recorded in 2010. And also, let me mention supply activities which have contributed for an additional €40 million versus last year, thanks to higher margin reported on the final customers.

Let's now move to Endesa results on slide – on the following slides. Well, as usual, first of all, let me remind you that the numbers we report on this slide and the following one are the results of the application of Enel Group's accounting principle, which may differ from Endesa's principle due to local standards. The Iberia division has recorded a decrease in EBITDA of about €493 million, or 11%. But net of the perimeter effect and the capital gains related to assets sold in 2010, 2011 EBITDA decreased by €100 million, or just of 2.4%.

This was mainly the results of a decline of €240 million in the liberalized business, which can be largely explained by the higher fuel costs and energy purchasing costs recorded as a consequence of the increased thermal output, lower hydro and nuclear contribution, coupled with higher prices; an increase of €70 million in the regulated business, mainly thanks to higher distribution revenues after the implementation of the Royal Decree issued during the course of 2008; and other items for €61 million that reflects the lower fixed costs related to the efficiency programs implemented by the company.

Now, let's turn to Latin America. Well, Latin America division has recorded an EBITDA decrease of €152 million or minus 4.5%. This is mainly the results of the following: €89 million of negative foreign exchange effect translation; a negative one-off impact of €109 million due to the full recognition of the net worth tax in Colombia, which will be paid every six months in eight installments between January 2011 and December 2014; an increase of €24 million in the generation business, mainly thanks to better hydro condition in Colombia due to the El Niño effects and higher prices in Peru, partially compensated for by lower margins in Chile compared to 2010 due to the drought which is affecting the country; an increase of €22 million in the distribution business, mainly thanks to higher volumes distributed in all the countries in which we operate that more than compensates the negative EBITDA of Argentina explained by higher costs as a consequence of inflation coupled with no tariff increase.

And now let's have a view of Enel Green Power in the following charts. Well, Enel Green Power totaled €1,585 million, representing an increase of €275 million or 21% up versus last year. This is mainly the results of the following: an increase of €53 million in Iberia and Latin America, which is mainly the results of the consolidation of ECyR for €41 million and overall higher prices in Iberia for €32 million; an increase of €23 million in North America, thanks to higher volumes in winds and hydro production and also thanks to a one-off positive impact of €16 million indemnity on a renewable plant expropriation; and finally, an increase of €184 million, mainly related to the fair value revaluation of some assets sold as well as the capital gain on the assets sold to Gas Natural.

Let's move to our net debt evolution. Well, overall, net debt decreased by about €300 million versus 2010, standing at about €44.6 billion. During this period, the cash flow from operations has enabled us to cover CapEx, debt services, taxes, and dividend payments, meanwhile releasing extra cash for net debt reduction. In particular, during the fourth quarter of 2011, the group has benefited from a very positive evolution of the operating cash flow, more than doubling vis-à-vis the third quarter, mainly thanks to our operations, the recovery of the seasonal working capital, and some regulatory cash-in items released in the last part of the year.

We are also improving our liquidity position. In fact, looking at this chart, it is clear that liquidity is not anymore an issue for the group. As you can see, we can count on about €30 billion of liquidity available which already covers existing debts – existing debt maturities through 2014 even taking into account 2012 short-term portion of debt maturities close to about €5 billion related to commercial paper and other credit lines which will be rolled over during the course of the year.
Thank you for your attention. And now, let me hand over to Fulvio Conti to take you through our 2012 short-term outlook and our 2012-2016 strategic plan.

Thanks, Luigi. I'm now going to start illustrating in this section the short-term macro environment in 2012. Let me start with a slide that shows basically the current economic scenario that we're facing, particular in Italy and in particular to the GEM division.

Despite the slight increase recorded in 2011 versus 2012 and the expected partial recovery in 2012 versus 2011, electricity demand evolution in Italy will remain weak. Increasing overcapacity and gas oversupply will continue to test market balance during 2012. In fact, we're expecting that 2008 demand level will not be recovered up to 2014. During 2011, the system overcapacity has worsened, mainly driven by the last and final CCGT additions and by a huge increase in solar photovoltaic capacity. Even assuming a lower path of solar increase going forward, 2012 will end up with a total solar capacity installed of at least 15 gigawatt.

As a consequence, the 2012 reserve margin in Italy, when put pressure on spark spreads that would drop by about €5 per megawatt hour versus 2011, of course. This has already been indicated by Luigi, and I confirm it to you. The persisting low level of gas demand in 2012, sorry, and versus 2008 has put additional pressure on operators facing take-or-pay obligations. As a consequence, the wholesale prices, which represents a relevant benchmark for power price, has declined.

However, notwithstanding this gas oversupply, as you all know, combined cycles are running on long-term oil-linked gas contracts. And this will continue to play an important role in the Italian wholesale market. As a consequence of all of this, we do expect GEM EBITDA for 2012 to be in the region of €1.3 billion.

Moving to Spain, 2012 outlook will be characterized by a slight decline in demand versus 2011. And looking at the most recent data of GDP growth, which will show a decline of 1.5% in 2012, we are assuming that electricity demand will not recover at the 2008 level, not earlier than 2014, as we've seen in Italy. The main drivers which explain the decline of 2012 EBITDA are the normalization, the last resort tariff, the Tarifa de Ultimo Recurso; as well as the higher impact from the social bonus, the bonus itself; expected lower margins in the Irelands, affected by the gas, electricity interconnection; and the non-recurring profits in gas contracts we negotiated which we have recorded back in 2011.

In Latam, Enel's operating performance will benefit from the good macroeconomic environment in this region. We are expecting electricity demand to grow by about 4% and generation output to grow by 5%. EBITDA is expected to grow by 10% in 2012, mainly driven by increased output in generation on new capacity and the hydro conditions and by the positive effect of the net worth tax in Colombia already paid in 2011 which will now be represented again.

Now let me turn to Russia and Slovakia. In Russia, we're forecasting in the short-term EBITDA to remain stable at €500 million, while dark and spark spreads will continue to rise. We now expect a delay in the gas netback parity versus the prior years, up to 2023, but yet again, with sparks and darks spreads growing, slower than the past, but still growing. In Slovakia, we are forecasting a stable EBITDA equal to €800 million. All in all, Russia and Slovak Republic continues to maintain their profitability levels at a stable scenario.

Let's move to renewables. We're currently investing in new capacity for almost two gigawatt, which one gigawatt would be delivered during 2012, thus reaching at the end of the year a total of net installed capacity of 1.1 gigawatt, stable load factor at 40%. Under this scenario, EBITDA is expected to increase to about €1.7 billion in 2012.

Now having said that, on 2012-2016, let me give you an update on the plan assumptions. Starting with 2013-2014, mature markets are expected to gradually recover and emerging markets will continue to show growth performance which is reflected in higher electricity demand.

Our balanced mix of markets leaves us with place – well-placed to benefit from growth in emerging markets while consolidating our positive – our position in mature markets – mature areas. One important feature is the CO2 scenario. And the good news is that we are balanced. As you all know, CO2 price scenario is strongly affected by decisions of the European Union, which are currently under discussion. You may have heard about setting quantity aside.

Let me also remind you that total cumulative emissions at the group level during the 2012-2016 amounts to a total of 350 million tons. Nevertheless, a large part of emissions are already covered by our internal portfolio. In fact, total CO2 credit portfolio, including international offset and EUY in the period of 2012-2016 amounts to 207 million tons. Furthermore, the mix of generation imply a natural balance allowing the nat short position in Italy to offset the natural long position in other countries. In particular, the natural short position of GEM is almost completely hedged up to 2015.

Now let's move into our strategic focus of the plan period. Consistent with previous years, our priorities for the plan period remain on maintaining our leadership in mature energy markets; delivering future organic growth from developing markets in Latam, Russia and Eastern Europe as well as on renewables; accelerating our efficiency plans and ongoing operations of excellence; keeping tight control on CapEx spending; providing leadership in cutting edge technologies; and finally, pursuing a strategy of net debt reduction to ensure our long-term financial stability.

More specifically, let me direct your attention to mature markets, starting with the Italian operations. Given the economic scenario that we have commented earlier, our major tasks in the Italian market is to maintain a focus on the operational excellence and CapEx optimization. This will be achieved through a number of actions like maximizing synergies and continuing with the implementation of our Zenith project, working capital optimization, as well as focusing on upgrading and improving efficiency of the existing fleet, protecting margins through hedging, and portfolio optimization.

We'll also strengthen our leadership in the free market pursuing selective growth opportunities in mass market and small/home office segments. This will go together with a tight attention on maintaining cost leadership and quality of service to final customers. Finally, we will not miss the ongoing use of innovative technologies developing smart grids and electric mobility tools.

Turning to the overall financial targets in this division, the result of this plan will be approximately €7.1 billion of CapEx in Italy between 2012-2016, mainly focused on investments in regulated activities, characterized by stable, high-returning established by the authority, and maintain investment in generation. We've also maintained a steady floor of €5.3 billion of EBITDA in Italian operations.

Finally, Iberia, we'll manage our relationship with regulators. We'll continue to focus on maximize synergies and executing Zenith plan. Our CapEx program will be characterized by selected just-in-time investments. Our reorganization in distribution segments is progressing well and will complete during this plan period, helping to increase overall efficiency of the operations. Lastly, with all of these initiatives, we'll strive to maintain high standards of service and continue to modernize our grid.

Let's turn to the overall financial targets for the division. During the plan period, Iberian CapEx will mainly focus on investments in distribution activities providing higher profitability, installation on new digital meters and favorable insular scenario in terms of electricity demand and new capacity, in particular in the Canary Islands. Also medium term growth in Iberian operations EBITDA will be driven by regulated business demand and price recovery.

Now let me turn the attention to the growth markets, Latam. In Latam, we'll consolidate our leadership position through a number of initiatives. In generation, we will add about one gigawatt of capacity and prepare ground for more investment in the outer years. In distribution, we will add 1.8 million new clients in the period. We will achieve new regulatory model in Argentina possibly, pursue control chain simplification and companies consolidation. We will also continue to focus on maximizing synergies in the Zenith plan as well as operational excellence. And finally, in line with our overall goals, we will optimize cash flow through selective investment policy.

The result of this will be CapEx program focused on building new capacity, Bocamina II, El Quimbo, Talara, (33:27); enhancing our presence in the area leveraging about 1.8 million customers to be connected, as I've said. And these investments will be supported by a favorable regulatory environment, encouraging investments in distribution to follow increasing connecting demand. Latam EBITDA will benefit from demand and price increases, new capacity additions and a generally favorable regulatory scenario.

Next, International operation, which we'll seek to strengthen the existing marketing positioning. In Slovakia, we will focus on organic growth and margins protection, leveraging on our know-how and technological expertise and increasing our market position in the Centrel area. In Russia, our focus will be organic growth through investment opportunities in CCGTs as well as in the improvement on our existing fleet reliability, efficiency, and fulfillment of environmental commitments. All of these will help us strengthening our position on the international operations.

More specifically, within these two markets, we will be selectively deploying capital to completing the one gigawatt of new nuclear capacity in Slovakia during 2013 and 2014 and some refurbishment investments in Russia on coal and gas generation. Taking into account international operations performance, EBITDA will be driven by higher volumes of electricity produced, thanks to the new capacity entering into operations in 2013 and 2014, favorable improvement in the generation spreads, and in the specific case of Russia, the opportunities of gas supplies to OGK-5 power plant from our 20% in seven Energia fields which will provide additional price benefits and hedge gas supply risks.

In this regard, let me also add in the next few weeks, these seven Energia fields will start producing, which will be extremely good news for all of us in the second half of the decade, will account for about one quarter of all of the non-gas from gas produced in Russia. Just to give you an idea how strong our position will be at that point.

Finally, on renewables operations, the maximization of value through the leverage on continuing shift investments from mature markets to emerging ones and managing the pipelines selectively, establishing operation and maintenance, world-class know-how and leveraging global business development and EPC teams set up in the last few years, monitoring the evolution on new technologies like concentrated solar thermodynamic and small biomass and developing new predictive tools in hybrid plants.

Our investments in renewables during the plan period will focus on increasing our footprint in those areas where the combination of resources availability and need for additional energy create a sustainable platform for renewables regardless of regulatory support. This will ensure an increasing diversification of existing footprint towards markets outside Europe. The CapEx plan is confirmed at €6 billion and will lead to about 11.6 gigawatt of total capacity installed by 2016 versus the 7.1 gigawatt at the end of 2011.

Against this macroeconomic backdrop in investment plan, what are we doing to secure value creation? Over the next few slides, I will outline a clear program of actions aimed at increasing our presence in growth markets, offsetting the challenge of our mature markets. Within our mature markets, we will invest in new pumping storage opportunities in Spain, backup capacity and efficiency projects in Italy. We will also leverage high value-added and innovative project based on smart meters and electric mobility among others. And finally, we will utilize our customer base as a platform to enhance revenues.

Moving to our growth markets. Our investment strategy in these markets will serve as a tool to deliver overall profitability growth at a group level. This will be accomplished through adding 4.5 gigawatt of capacity in renewables, 1.1 gigawatt in Latam, one gigawatt in Slovakia, and some refurbishment investments in Russia, as we already commented; leveraging technological and geographical diversification across the group; pursuing supportive regulation to enhance profitability in Latam; improving efficiency in regulatory businesses.

We will also take the opportunity to reassess the mix of our capital allocation to current economic environment, with a more focused and effective CapEx program, through investment allocation and efficiency that will bring lower CapEx in mature markets and the new efficiency project called Optima CapEx, adding another €1 billion of cash savings.

Let me focus your attention, if you wish, on efficiencies, starting with Enel-Endesa synergies program. We have reached €1.3 billion target as for 2011. And this level would be maintained throughout this plan and beyond. In addition, we'll continue to deliver our Zenith programs which will contribute about €6 billion of cumulative cash in the period of 2009-2015.

On top of these programs, we have launched another initiative which we call One Company Project, which aims at establishing a lean holding together with centralized global service units. This initiative will bring yearly cost savings at the tune of €400 million starting from 2016.

Now, what does all this mean for our group in terms of financial targets? First, dividends. As long as the current situation of financial constraints and lack of liquidity in the financial markets persists, the dividend payout will tend to a gradual reduction on dividends payment for all subsidiaries. Under these new policies, Enel Group will distribute about €11 billion to shareholders between 2012 and 2016, of which about €3.5 billion will go to our minorities. We believe this approach will allow us to ensure growth coupled with long-term financial stability, despite the difficult macro environment and to enhance cash flows available for the net debt reduction.

In fact, through the action we have outlined today during the plan period, we will increase our capacity for net debt reduction to €14.5 billion versus the €9 billion in the previous plan. To summarize what this means for our overall financial targets taking into account the macroeconomic factors we discussed at the start of this presentation, we have revised our short and long-term targets.

Our 2012 EBITDA target stands at €16.5 billion rising to €19 billion by 2016. Ordinary net income is projected at about €3.4 billion for 2012 rising to €5 billion in 2016. This increase will be supported by growth in developing markets as well as the initiatives we have taken to sustain margins, drive efficiency and cost savings, all across the group. Financial discipline is a key feature of this plan. Our prudent approach to CapEx and dividends will enable us to deliver nearly €15 billion net debt reduction by 2016.

Let me conclude by saying that most of the uncertainties, if not all, on financial distress and fiscal policies are now over. And we remain confident that through the managerial action that we have put in place, Enel will be well-placed to pursue long-term growth.
Thank you very much for your attention. And now, let me move to question-and-answers.

Thank you. So let's start with questions, reminding that we have people here in the room but also questions from people connected on the website. I remind you that this event is being broadcasted live on the Web. So first question here, maybe Susanna Invernizzi, Lehman. Can stand up please, Susanna? Thank you.

Susanna Invernizzi, Barclays unfortunately, not Lehman. It is now. Well, I have several questions. First of all, if you can elaborate a little bit more on the reduction of the GEM target for EBITDA in 2012? So how much is associated to spreads, demand, and other – eventually other issues?

Second, on the CapEx plan, again, if I may have more information on the CapEx reduction, so which were the main area of reduction versus your previous plan? And also looking at your available lines, maybe if you can give us little more details on the term loan that you have raised in February, the duration and any details on that? Thank you.

Should we answer right away? The GEM targets obviously are influenced by the impact of this double effect of the overcapacity coming from the photovoltaic growth. Dramatic expansion of photovoltaic had the impact on us because it is working at the peak hours, shaving to some extent the extra pricing that you might get during peak hours. And the other impact is coming from the effect of this gas situation of Italy. This combined creates this five gigawatt of – sorry, five gigahertz of spread, which is missing in 2012 versus 2011.

Demand is not growing that much. It's stable and therefore the combination of all of this is definitely a lower EBITDA. Is this a transition versus more bad news? No, I would not consider that to be a moment of passage. It will be in my view in terms of possibly the bottom because what we might be seeing the next year a slight increase of demand. What will I see – we'd like to see? A bit more of gas markets being driven by the LatAm countries. There is no infrastructure to make leeways for more spot pricing gas into the market. And the slowdown in the growth of the photovoltaic is also another positive element. So all in rate, I think, when we say that the margins will be a floor of €5.3 billion EBITDA in the plan, we are pretty confident this might be the outcome.

Let me speak about CapEx reductions. We applying here the just-in-time principle. We had and we still have wonderful projects to be deployed in terms of expanding our presence in the Italian market or the Spanish market, but demand is not thee to justify for the time being. So you can easily postpone those investments, complete the existing ones, and therefore having a well-balanced position and the commitment you have today versus what you might take in the future.

And on this, again, our driving towards supporting more the regulated business, not only in Italy and Spain but also in the fast economies – fast growing economies on South America, is giving you the idea that we are allocating a bit more capital into distribution. We maintain our renewable €6 billion of CapEx because we believe there is a wonderful resource available in those economies that we are in the space of, the Americas, for instance, and the remaining portion will be those investments – those selective investments in generation and distribution capacity in the mature markets, which will bridge the gap between now and the moment when the overall demand will continue to see growth, even in Italy and Spain.

That's the combination of all decisions that we have been taking on the €27 billion of capital. It's lower than the past because there is less of a need of incremental capacity since demand is not growing. So it's no-brainer. It's an easy decision to take. When it comes to the term loan, Luigi, can you talk about it?

Let me take the opportunity to update you about what we have done during the course of the first two months of this year. In total, we have raised about €7.3 billion of funds with an average maturity of six years and with a cost only of about 4.8%. This is including, of course, the bond retail issuance, some private placements and the term loan facility you were talking about.
Okay. Next question. Roberto Letizia, would you please stand up?

Yes. Thank you. Roberto Letizia from Equita SIM. Lot of changes so need to better understand what are the underlying assumptions of the plan. And the first need I have is understand what the rating from a credit perspective you have used for the plan? So if it's still A or BBB+? And in case you changed the assumption over there, if you can better let me understand what's the impact from both financial and operational side, meaning how much of the debt have step up clause, for example, on the rating and the cost of debt? And if there is any operational impact, for example, on the hedging activities on the forward sales on the rating impact, anyway which rating has been used?

And then especially for with regards Spain, which kind of assumption has been used in terms of possible regulatory revision to be taking in the few month, if there is any? On the CapEx, a follow-up from Susanna, just better understanding. If you can give us the split annually for 2012 and 2013 on the CapEx and if specifically your CapEx assumption exclude any investment for Porto Tolle and Porto Empedocle in case it includes how much of it? And that's it for the moment. Thank you.

Well, let me tackle the first question you have. You have to consider the situation the world is at this very moment and in particular Europe. The newspapers are full of news about what's going to happen to Greece, what has been the major concerns in sovereign funds, sovereign debt, global comp out being approved, being referendum, being I don't know what. I don't need to remind you the overall conditions of the economies we're living in. We are reflecting a dramatic change. We've been lucky and able, more than lucky, to be resilient in the past few years. When the crisis have been biting the cheeks of many different players in the market, we have been resisting because we had the good combination of assets, because we had a diversification of markets, because we had cost savings programs going on.

But with the continuing trend, negative trends of the economies, if we will not be changing and adapting ourselves to the changing world, you would have looked at us as fools. We're not fools. We're sensible managers working for the long-term value creation for our shareholders and bondholders. And that's what we're trying to give you as a message today. This plan is predicated not on single ratings, predicating on the ability to carry on with growth, maintaining financial stability, namely being able to prove that no matter what's going on in the world, whatever financial crisis will occur, the company will be up and running and possibly increasing profitability as we do plan to increase profitability.

And this has got nothing to do with the rating. I do believe that what we have here is a plan that will justify – amply justify single A rating. But if the Italian Republic is going down to BBB, as other countries are suffering for the same downgrading by Standard & Poor's, should we expect to be an exception? You'll have learned over the years that it's difficult to stay above one single country level.

That's the key assumption that we're making. We are making the assumption that no matter what the overall world will look like, a year from now, two years from now, three years from now, we stand up with our programs, plans, CapEx, cash flows to benefit from the many opportunities that the market will continue to deliver because we're selling and generating electricity. We have less volatility in other markets because we are an energy company with a composite yet performing asset managers that can deliver. So stay tuned with this and we'll get to you good news.
Spain, I didn't get to the answer but we have here...
We have other regulatory in Spain.
We have the top officers of Spain in the name of the Chairman and CEO and they can deliver.

I guess the question was on what kind of assumptions on regulatory issues were made for the plan and the – actually the only way we could do it and the way we did it is assuming that the present regulatory set up would continue throughout the five years.
